msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum, Charles Fairfax Murray MS 17

msContents.textLang: Middle English and Latin, with some Middle French

msItem.title: The Secret of Astronomy
msItem.rubric: 1r Here begynyth þe secret of Astronom[y]
msItem.incipit: 1r When the science of astronomy hath ben harde yn the harte of the beholder though of the composicioun of olde philosofers we haue yn many bokys In whiche all secretys of the Science of doctrinys of all philosophers shortly to gader ynto one whiche yn 12 causes compendiousy I haue departyd
msItem.explicit: 28v-29r Therfor þis boke present take hys ende yff god wyll the which ys the pryncipall begynner and spryngar of all scyens with ys blessyd yn the world without ende Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 29r Opus multum vtile quod ait [erasure] AMEN
msItem.note: Features a prologue and twelve chapters of astrological advice on finding lost objects. The text proper begins on f. 2r. An explicit has been added on the empty space of an erased name that was part of the original explicit: Explicit feliciter.

msItem.title: Astrological text for finding lost objects
msItem.rubric: 29r To know the thyng that \is/ takyn a waye
msItem.incipit: 29r Knowe þou with what ster the ☾ is yf she be with ♄ hit shall be yer[...] or led or a blake thyng
msItem.explicit: 29v ☿ Syngnyfith sotyll sotyll caussys and sotyll werkes grauyn or writtynges or sourain bokes or women thynges and soo forther

msItem.title: Astrological text to find fugitives
msItem.rubric: 29v To knowe to what partes of the world the figife [sic] is gone or onny oþer thynges þat is agone loke yf þe ☾ be in þe ascendent or in þe 10 7 or 4 then þe fugitife is gone to þe quarter wher þe ☾ be and yf þe ☾ be not in non of the 4 quarters than beholde þe lorde of the syne þat thi ☾ is in and iudge be hym wher he is for toward þat parte þe figitife is gonn.
msItem.note: Full transcription, as in Rand (2006), p. 80 [see also for other copies].

msItem.title: Charm for undefined purpose
msItem.incipit: 30r Scribe: Bursse . Henrico / Marsse . Henrico - vppon a hasel shute of one yeares grouth et nomen pacientis caste it in ignem - probatur et probaui
msItem.note: Full transcription; copied by a 16th-century hand; the same hand that copied the medical recipe on f. 30r.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for removing a tooth
msItem.incipit: 30r Put the powder of red corall in the hollowe tooth and he shall fall on the grownde - non probaui
msItem.note: Full transcription; copied by a 16th-century hand; the same hand that copied the charm on f. 30r.

msItem.title: Recipe for salve for plaster
msItem.rubric: 30v Entret for Akyn or brusyng of a wonde
msItem.incipit: 30v Take fatte bacoun of a hole swyne and milt it and lett it stande till the salt be full be the grounde then take that and as much of virgyn wex and recles and boyle to gethir and put ther to stoure and poudred and stere till it be thicke as hony and lay it on cloth or on lether and do it to the fyre and that will drawe away the ache and what evyll thou haue lay it ther to
msItem.note: Full transcription, as in Rand (2006), p. 80. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Treatise on prognostics [Capsula eburnea]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Hippocrates
Gerard of Cremona [translator]
msItem.incipit: 31r [P]eruenit ad nos quod um ypocras morti approroquaret [sic: appropinquaret] precepit ut virtutes istius scripture in libro ponerentur in capsula eburnea et ponerentur ipsa cum eo in sepulcro suo
msItem.explicit: 31r Et est signum quod accidit ei in principio sue egritudinis desiderium dulcium desiderio vehementer

msItem.title: Treatise on symptoms of diseases according to which day of the month they begin
msItem.incipit: 34r [S]ignis prima die cuiuscumque mensis in infirmitate ceciderit sequens tercia dies timenda est quam si transierit infirmus vsque a xxx dies euadet
msItem.explicit: 35v Qui vero in xxxmo die deciderit vtrum infirmus euadet anno non duium est
msItem.note: Copied by the same hand that copied ff. 31r-34r.

msItem.title: A dietary and regimen for every month, translation of the Dieta ypocratis [Dicta ypocratis]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Galen
msItem.incipit: 35v-36r Galien the leche techith of mete and drynke to vsen and the tyme of blode letyng for all maner goutes and seken\e/s in mannes body or in legges - In the moneth of Januer white wyne is gode to drynke fastyng and bledyng forbere for any thynge vij dayes ther vij dayes thervith of perell the j. ij. iiij. v. x. xv and the xix vse no drynke thath makith thy bely loce but lectuaries thou may take and vse
msItem.explicit: 38r In the moneth of December ete hote metes and for nede then in aye be lett blod and caulewortes forbere and who so will such lyve lede the sekerer he maye be of his helth also iij. dayes there bith of perill for to bled the vj. the vij. and the xv. the lasse bledyng the better in this moneth.

msItem.title: Rules for bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 38v [T]he masters that vsen blode letyng / And therby gete their lyvyng
msItem.explicit: 40v So that godde be helpyng / The wich bryngith all to gode endyng

msItem.title: Treatise on astrological prognostication
msItem.author: Pseudo-Roger Bacon
msItem.incipit: 41r Notandum est that yn euery Jugement ther ben .4. thinges to be sowte scilicet the nature of the planet that shall be the significator / And of the signe whiche it ys yn. And of the signe whiche shalbe þe ascendent . And of þe signe that shalb[e] the house / And so of euery pertener with Jugement
msItem.explicit: 59r-59v for byng and selling and yf the lord of assendant be found in the 7 than the byer dessyrth to to [sic] bey of the seller and yf the lord of the 7 be found in the assendant than then [sic] the seller dessyryth the byer
msItem.note: A later hand has added the explicit: Explicit feliciter.

msItem.title: Astrological note on questions asked at different times
msItem.incipit: 59v Yffe the questyon be axyd in the houre of .♂. or .☿. then it is so yf itt be asked in the oure of the .☉. of .♀. of .☾. of .♃. or .♄. then itt is not soo.
msItem.note: Full transcription, as in Rand (2006), p. 81. The rubric has been left unifnished.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for Gratia Dei
msItem.textLang: Latin recipe with Middle English plant names
msItem.incipit: 60r [M]edicina indeficiens que gracia dei nuncupatur
msItem.explicit: 60v Postea deponatur ab igne et ponatur turpentine florac. calamynte dragmas tres balsami dragma j. et Semper augeatur cum spatula usque infrigida inter postea malaxetur et vsui reseruetur
msItem.note: Copied by the same hand that copied ff. 31r-34r.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes (c. 40)
msItem.textLang: Thirty-five English and six Latin recipes
msItem.note: Copied by the same hand that copied ff. 31r-34r.

msItem.title: On the virtues of fifteen different herbs
msItem.incipit: 75v Take pympernell turmentill veruayne spurgnell for thay clensith of ech of the [one handful] betayne for the feuere
msItem.explicit: 75v pety consoude redde docke gratia dei for thay souden of eche [one handful]
msItem.note: See Rand (2006), p. 82 for a full transcription. The text ends with the added explicit: explicit feliciter.

msItem.title: Tract on the five magical virtues of vervain
msItem.rubric: 76r Vervena est herba quae habet pluras virtutes
msItem.incipit: 76r Vna est istas . ponatur in signa omnes pisces congregabuntur ad illum locum
msItem.explicit: 76r Item si homo portat eum inimicus non nocebit eius et si ista volueris operare oportet et sic colligere luna plena existente mense may tunc herba valet ad omnes has virtutes
msItem.note: The text explains how one case use vervain to catch fish, to determine whether a woman is a virgin, become invisible (which can only be countered with holy water), discover the identity of a thief, and become invulnerable to enemies.
Below the text, another hand has started a note: Here John ssodayne [?].

msItem.title: Instructions for collecting and administring the herbs vervain and valerian for medical purposes
msItem.incipit: 76v Accipe veruenam [...] ortum solis luna crescente et freta eam inter manus tuas et fac puluerem vel aliquam de ea et da bibere vel manducare etcaetera. Item accipe valerianum autem ortum solis luna crescente dicendo in colligendo istud euangelium In principio et thoche in lachez [...] freta eam in manus tuas et et da eam manducare et bibere et sanabitur

msItem.title: On the Sphere of Pythagoras
msItem.rubric: 77r-77v Probata fuit hec spera pigtagora per dominum henricus ducem lancastre coram Rege Francie pugnante et de domino Johanne de Amesley onore dominorum hec scuta presencia sunt.
msItem.incipit: 77v Pronosticatio pictagoris summam philosophi secundum operam presentem de vita et de morte de Egrotantibus et de preliantibus seu pugnantibus ac de sponsaliis et longis itineribus magnis operibus incipiendis et negotiis aliis
msItem.explicit: 78v Et pronostica de eo sicut de ceteris dictus est. Finis [erasure]
msItem.note: The text begins with a drawing of the Sphere of Pythagoras, below which two coats of arms have been added with the inscriptions: Duces lancastre and Johannes de amis[ley]. The latter may have been added in the 16th or 17th century.

msItem.title: Diagram and tables concerning the Twelve Mansions of the Moon
msItem.incipit: 79r In quibus domibus Planeta gaudent
msItem.note: Begins with a nativity chart and ends with a table, entitled Tabula terminorum.

msItem.title: Note on giving prognostic advice about another's journey
msItem.rubric: 80v Yf one aske of the whether he shall be take or trubld in his iornay
msItem.incipit: 80v Behold þe 12 and his lord and yff the lord of þe 12 be in the fryst or elles þe lord of þe 1 be in þe 12 or with þe lord of þe 12 the [sic] he shall be put in presoun and yf hit be not this hit shall not be soo
msItem.note: Full transcription, as in Rand (2006), p. 82. Added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Table of zodiacal signs and planets
msItem.rubric: 81r To knowe þe dygnygtes of planets ye schull [...] streinthe of hys hows hathe 5 dignites [...] by hy triplycite 3 by hys terme 2 and [...]
msItem.note: The page has been cropped, causing loss of text.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are headed To make gresse pouder al serpyntyne and Corne pouder.

msItem.title: List of latitudes of English towns and foreign cities
msItem.incipit: 82r Lestera 53.55 Lyncoon 53 Eboraci [crossed out: 5] 54
msItem.note: Copied by the same hand that copied ff. 31r-34r.

msItem.title: Prognostic note on the number of husbands a woman will have
msItem.rubric: 82v Who many husbands a wyff shall haue
msItem.incipit: 82v If a man demaund for ony woman how many husband she shall haue be holde fro þe lord of the 10 vntyll the degry of ♂ and as many planettes as þou doust feynd betwyxt them so many husbondes she shall haue and yff ♂ be in the 7 housh be holde from mars to Jupiter and Judge after þe same maner
msItem.note: Full transcription, as in Rand (2006), p. 83. Added in the early 16th century.

msItem.title: Prognostic note on the number of wives a man will have
msItem.rubric: 82v + How many wyuys a man shall haue
msItem.incipit: 82v Be hold from þe 10 housh to ♀ and so many planetes as ther be so many wyuys þe man shall haue
msItem.note: Full transcription, as in Rand (2006), p. 83. Added in the early 16th century. The name Peter has been written next to the rubric by a different hand.

msItem.title: Ten medical recipes (largely for remedies against syphilis)
msItem.note: The collection includes nine recipes ffor the ffrensch pockes (syphilis), and one for treating all maner hurtes olde or newe.

msItem.title: Account of medical ingredients and their prices
msItem.incipit: 86r Colofone - J li. viijd
msItem.explicit: 86r Oyle of camell J li. ijs viijd

msItem.title: List of the planets and their astrological symbols
msItem.rubric: 86v The figurez of the vij planetes
msItem.incipit: 86v This is the ffigure of sol ☉
msItem.note: The text is largely faded.

msItem.title: List of the signs of the Zodiac combined with the astrological symbols of planets
msItem.incipit: 86v Aries ♈︎ ♃
msItem.note: The text is partially faded.

supportDesc.support: Parchment (HFFH), except for the last quire which consists of paper leaves with parchment outer and inner leaves (ff. 76, 81, 86). It has not been possible to check the paper leaves for watermarks because the manuscript is tightly bound and should not be opened further than 45 degrees.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos. Folios [a] and [b] are unfoliated lifted pastedowns consisting of translucent paper. Folios i and iv are translucent paper leaves. Folios ii and iii are paper flyleaves. Folio [ii]a is an unfoliated paper pastedown on f. ii. Flyleaves [a], [iia], and [b] are unfoliated in the manuscript but have been allocated letters and numbers for referencing purposes in this electronic catalogue record.
Numbering in brown ink at the center of the upper margins of all rectos and versos (excluding flyleaves, which have not been numbered in the pagination sequence).

list.item: Quire 1012-3+1 (ff. 76v-86v: 6th-7th leaves, after f. 80, and one other leaf cancelled; and one parchment leaf, f. 81, added to the stub of the cancelled 7th leaf)

p.formula: 1-68 710+1 (11th inserted) 8-98 1012 (6th-7th and one other leaf cancelled; and one parchment leaf added to the stub of 7th)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown frames written on the right lower corner of the last verso of Quires 2 and 6 (i.e. ff. 16v and 48v.

layout.seg: Ruled in brown ink, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 13-19 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: A scribe working in a cursive script with bâtarde [bastarda] features copied ff. 1r-29v and 41r-59v.

Various scribes working in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features (although to varying degrees, and some have stronger anglicana features) copied ff. 30r-40v, 59v-76v, 79r-81v, and 82v-86v.
A scribe working in a cursive anglicana script copied ff. 77r-78v, and 82r.

decoNote.p: Astrological diagrams (nativity charts) drawn in brown or red ink on ff. 8r, 55r, and 79r.
Sphere of Pythagoras drawn in dark ink on f. 77r, accompanied by drawings of two coats of arms in dark ink and higlighted in yellow ink.
Headings, incipits explicits, and display script, written in red ink; arabic numerals and astrological symbols drawn in red ink.
Horizontal bars with knotwork motifs in dark ink occur between sections or at the end of texts to mark textual divisions on f. 26r and f. 59v.

note.p: Modern quire numbers added in pencil to the outer lower corners of the first rectos of quires.
A printed description of the manuscript's contents on a folded paper pasted onto f. ii recto.
A table listing the manuscript's contents, by a 17th-century hand on f. iii recto.

binding.p: 16th-century dark brown leather over (?) pasteboards, gold-tooled, with oval medallions of strapwork design on both covers; the spine with three raised bands, gold-tooled, and with gold-stamped flowers. Red-speckled fore-, head, and tail edges.
Binding height: 155 mm; width: 110 mm; depth: 30 mm.

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts of Bertram Ashburnham (1797-1878) Ashburnham, Betram, 1797-1876, 4th Earl of Ashburnham: was Asburnham Appendix 121; see the third pastedown on f. [a] verso: From the Library of the Earl of Ashburnham Appendix N. o LXXI May 1897, with the added inscription: Sold 1899 (69), referring to the sale of his library by Sotheby's on 1 May 1899, where this manuscript was lot 69 (see Catalogue of a portion of the collection of manuscripts known as the "Appendix", from whose printed catalogue the descriptions are taken [...] Which will by sold by auction, by Messrs. Sotheby, Wilkinson and Hodge [...] the 1st day of May, 1899 (Dryden press, J. Davy and sons, 1899), p. 40 [Lost 69].) .

Owned by Charles Fairfax Murray (1849–1919) Fairfax Murray, 1849–1919, artist and art connoisseur: his ownership is indicated by a paper pastedown with his printed ex libris on f. [a] verso: From the Library of Ch: Fairfax Murray, with the added handwritten note 17; the same page also features a donation bookplate, which states that the manuscript was presented to the Fitzwilliam Museum by him in 1905.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Fitzwilliam Museum in 1905: as indicated by a donation bookplate on [a] verso: Fitzwilliam Museum Cambridge [MS CFM 17] Presented by [Charles Fairfax Murray - 1905].

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on the descriptions provided by Francis Wormald Wormald, Francis,1904-1972 and Phyllis M. Giles, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Additional Illuminated Manuscripts in the Fitzwilliam Museum Acquired between 1895 and 1979 (Excluding the McClean Collection), 2 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Library, 1982), I: pp. 30-32 and Kari Anne Rand, Handlist XVIII: Manuscripts in the Library of Pembroke College, and the Fitzwilliam Museum, The Index of Middle English Prose (Cambridge: Woodbridge, 2006), pp. 79-82.

availability.p: Visitors to the Fitzwilliam Museum who wish to consult Collection material are required to apply to the Museum in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Fitzwilliam Museum: Study Room.

monogr.title: A descriptive catalogue of the additional illuminated manuscripts in the Fitzwilliam Museum acquired between 1895 and 1979 (excluding the McClean Collection)
Manuscripts in the Library of Pembroke College, Cambridge and the Fitzwilliam Museum

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
